user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_set_connection_value_n:
```c
_MHD_EXTERN enum MHD_Result
MHD_set_connection_value_n (struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                            enum MHD_ValueKind kind,
                            const char *key,
                            size_t key_size,
                            const char *value,
                            size_t value_size)
{
  if ( (MHD_GET_ARGUMENT_KIND != kind) &&
       ( ((key ? strlen (key) : 0) != key_size) ||
         ((value ? strlen (value) : 0) != value_size) ) )
    return MHD_NO; /* binary zero is allowed only in GET arguments */

  return MHD_set_connection_value_n_nocheck_ (connection,
                                              kind,
                                              key,
                                              key_size,
                                              value,
                                              value_size);
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function MHD_set_connection_value_n:
static enum MHD_Result
MHD_set_connection_value_n_nocheck_ (struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                                     enum MHD_ValueKind kind,
                                     const char *key,
                                     size_t key_size,
                                     const char *value,
                                     size_t value_size)
{
  struct MHD_HTTP_Req_Header *pos;

  pos = MHD_connection_alloc_memory_ (connection,
                                      sizeof (struct MHD_HTTP_Res_Header));
  if (NULL == pos)
    return MHD_NO;
  pos->header = key;
  pos->header_size = key_size;
  pos->value = value;
  pos->value_size = value_size;
  pos->kind = kind;
  pos->next = NULL;
  /* append 'pos' to the linked list of headers */
  if (NULL == connection->rq.headers_received_tail)
  {
    connection->rq.headers_received = pos;
    connection->rq.headers_received_tail = pos;
  }
  else
  {
    connection->rq.headers_received_tail->next = pos;
    connection->rq.headers_received_tail = pos;
  }
  return MHD_YES;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I inspected both functions (MHD_set_connection_value_n and MHD_set_connection_value_n_nocheck_). MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 prohibits modifying a function parameter (the pointer variable itself), although the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified. In the provided code there are no assignments to any parameter variables — i.e. there is no statement like connection = ..., kind = ..., key = ..., key_size = ..., value = ..., or value_size = ....

Relevant observations that justify not flagging any fragments:
- MHD_set_connection_value_n only compares parameters and forwards them to MHD_set_connection_value_n_nocheck_. No parameter is assigned to or modified.
- MHD_set_connection_value_n_nocheck_ assigns the parameter values into fields of the newly allocated struct (pos->header = key; pos->header_size = key_size; pos->value = value; pos->value_size = value_size; pos->kind = kind). Storing a parameter’s value into another object does not modify the parameter variable itself and is allowed by Rule 17.8.
- The code modifies the object pointed to by connection (e.g. updating connection->rq.headers_received_tail and linked-list pointers). Modifying the object referred to by a pointer parameter is permitted by the rule.
- There is no pointer arithmetic or re-assignment of pointer parameters, and key/value are declared as const char * (they are not modified).

Because no function parameter variable is reassigned or otherwise modified anywhere in the shown code, there are no fragments that need investigation for Rule 17.8.
